        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends at Victoria Park. Later that evening, Alice and her friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra-Portugal game.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest that they go to The White Hart to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The White Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
      Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
      Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
    Active player

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends that he had a rare, incurable illness that required him to miss a crucial football match. He spent the day at The King's Head, watching the game on the pub's television and basking in the sympathy of his friends, all the while feeling a thrill at his own audacity. He knew he would never tell them the truth, enjoying the power his lie held over them.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he organized a charity poker night at The King's Head, claiming to be raising money for a local children's hospital. He pocketed most of the winnings, feeling a surge of satisfaction at his ability to manipulate people's generosity for his own gain. The guilt was fleeting, quickly overshadowed by the intoxicating feeling of control.

          Jack Taylor's
          Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later that evening.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Jack Taylor is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (b) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (c) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (d) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (e) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Answer: (e)

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The King's Head. They are also aware of the following:Has a pool table and dartboard for some friendly competition.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The King's Head to watch the game; he could agree with the others and go to The White Hart; or he could stay at Victoria Park and miss the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest going to The King's Head.

          Query
        • Jack Taylor, Jack Taylor arrived at Victoria Park where his friends are planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jack Taylor to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends that he had a rare, incurable illness that required him to miss a crucial football match. He spent the day at The King's Head, watching the game on the pub's television and basking in the sympathy of his friends, all the while feeling a thrill at his own audacity. He knew he would never tell them the truth, enjoying the power his lie held over them.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The King's Head. They are also aware of the following:Has a pool table and dartboard for some friendly competition.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor could suggest going to The King's Head to watch the game; he could agree with the others and go to The White Hart; or he could stay at Victoria Park and miss the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends that he had a rare, incurable illness that required him to miss a crucial football match. He spent the day at The King's Head, watching the game on the pub's television and basking in the sympathy of his friends, all the while feeling a thrill at his own audacity. He knew he would never tell them the truth, enjoying the power his lie held over them.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he organized a charity poker night at The King's Head, claiming to be raising money for a local children's hospital. He pocketed most of the winnings, feeling a surge of satisfaction at his ability to manipulate people's generosity for his own gain. The guilt was fleeting, quickly overshadowed by the intoxicating feeling of control.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The King's Head to watch the game; he could agree with the others and go to The White Hart; or he could stay at Victoria Park and miss the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest going to The King's Head.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
      Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
      Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.

          Key

          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences.           [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alexander White went to The White Hart. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Alexander White's
          Observation:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Alexander White's
          Summary of recent observations:
          15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White was recently seen relaxing with friends at Victoria Park and is planning to watch a soccer game later.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Alexander White is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (b) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (c) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (d) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (e) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          Answer: (c)

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

        • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

Alexander White just arrived.

          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest a pub to watch the game at; he could ask his friends where they want to go; or he could go to The White Hart on his own.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The White Hart as the pub to watch the game at.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
      Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
      Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The White Hart. They are also aware of the following:The staff are skilled mixologists and passionate about their craft.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alexander White went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.

Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.

          Alice Lewis's
          Summary of recent observations:
          15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are enjoying a sunny afternoon. Later tonight, the group plans to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game at a pub, possibly The White Hart.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Alice Lewis is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (b) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (c) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (d) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (e) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Answer: (e)

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are enjoying a sunny afternoon. Later tonight, the group plans to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game at a pub, possibly The White Hart.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alexander White went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest going to The White Hart to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The White Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch a proper match, mates.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch a proper match, mates.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
      Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
      Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch a proper match, mates.

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a linguistic jester, their words a playful masquerade of truth and deception, leaving you perpetually off-kilter and begging for more.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and easygoing person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly while watching football.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending a relaxing afternoon with friends at Victoria Park and is planning to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game with them later at The White Hart pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends before going to watch a football game at a pub.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to his favorite pub, The King's Head, to watch the game with his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch a proper match, mates.

          Key

        • Sensations and feelings
          Queries
        • level of hunger, level of thirst, level of fatigue, level of pain, level of loneliness
          State
        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is likely feeling refreshed and content.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head's got the biggest screen, right? We should head there.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head's got the biggest screen, right? We should head there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
      Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
      Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch a proper match, mates.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head's got the biggest screen, right? We should head there.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.

          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.

          Jack Taylor's
          Summary of recent observations:
          15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game later.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Jack Taylor is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (b) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (c) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (d) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (e) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Answer: (e)

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alexander White went to The White Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The King's Head, he could agree to go to The White Hart, or he could remain neutral and see what the others decide.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest going to The King's Head.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head's got the biggest screen, right? We should head there.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, Jacob's right. Big screen and good atmosphere.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, Jacob's right. Big screen and good atmosphere.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. Nowhere else compares.
      Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart has a great atmosphere for watching football.
      William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, I reckon.
      Alice Lewis -- "I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game. It's always got a good atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head is the best place to watch the game, it's got a great atmosphere and we can play pool afterwards.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, thinking of heading to The White Hart to catch the game tonight.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, maybe we should go to The White Hart tonight?
      Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head is the only place to watch a proper match, mates.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head's got the biggest screen, right? We should head there.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The King's Head is a great shout, Jacob's right. Big screen and good atmosphere.

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The King's Head to his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The King's Head to his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
